Award.AwardTitle: 2017 Computational Methods and Function Theory Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the "Computational Methods and Function Theory 2017 Conference" that will be held at Lublin, Poland, 2017 during July 10-15, 2017.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of Geometric Function Theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: http://cmft2017.umcs.lublin.pl/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computational Methods and Function Theory 2017 conference brought together mathematicians from over 30 countries, and included students, beginning researchers, and leaders in the field of computational methods and function theory. The six day event included over 135 contributed talks, 10 plenary addresses, about 20 poster presentations, and a problem session. The quadrennial CMFT young reseracher award was presented to Nir Lev for his work on quasicrystals. The applications of the field to other areas are well known, and include numerical analysis, partial and ordinary differential equations, and areas of probability such as random matrices. Many of the talks given at the conference spoke directly to these applications and defined the state of the art in this field.

The scholarship and research developments presented at the conference have helped define directions for current and future research. Students and young reserachers ahd the opportunity to present preliminary results in poster form, and learn of important current problems in the problem session.

A special effort was made to to include students and young researchers. In particular the NSF grant enabled 11 graduate students and young researchers from the United States to participate in the conference. In addition, the grant funded the participation of two of the plenary speakers from the United States.
